And we were doing these real-time applications and using pieces of Backbone and then gradually adding more and more and more things on top of Backbone. And we find that most people that have production apps written in Backbone really use Backbone as a lower level framework and then they write their own framework on top of it, because it does a few things really well but it doesnâ€™t do everything that you need. And so, Ampersand, and thereâ€™s also this other weird problem with Backbone even though itâ€™s really small and modular. Itâ€™s tightly coupled. So, if you want to use some other model with Backbone collections itâ€™s a little bit tricky to do that. And so, thatâ€™s really what Ampersand is, is itâ€™s a collection of Backbone-like pieces [chuckles] that you can use to assemble an application. CHUCK:Â  So, itâ€™s not Backbone and itâ€™s not built on Backbone but itâ€™s like Backbone? HENRIK:Â  A lot of the code, at least to start, was from Backbone. Especially in the Node community thatâ€™s a big thing. HENRIK:Â  One of the issues that I personally had with it is, well really our team has, is the models for example are very loose. You can store absolutely anything you want on them.
